misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete program to compute the Euclidean distance between two points instead of implementing a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A–F) based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read coordinates for two points and compute the distance between them, rather than to read a numeric grade and map it to a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to check which range it falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: The class is named DistanceBetweenPoints and all variables refer to coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade.
The program prompts for and reads four double values using nextDouble() rather than a single numeric grade.
There are no conditional statements (if/else) to test grade ranges.
The output message reports the distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or wrote code for a different assignment (distance between points) and did not adapt it to the grade-calculator specification, indicating difficulty in mapping the written problem requirements to the correct program behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and list the required inputs, processing, and outputs. Then write a new program that (1) reads one numeric grade, (2) uses an if/else-if/else chain to test which range the grade is in, and (3) prints the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (class name, variables, prompts, calculations, and output) consistently implements a distance calculator, with no trace of grade-related logic or output.

evidence.note: The entire main method is devoted to reading coordinates and computing the distance between two points, with no grade input, no conditional grade ranges, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program designed to calculate the distance between two points (using coordinates x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of the required program to calculate a letter grade from a single numeric score (0-100). The code entirely fails to address the requirements of the Grade Calculator task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code satisfies the requirements for the Grade Calculator problem, likely due to submitting the wrong file or confusing the assignment prompts.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required program must accept one single integer input (the grade) and use conditional logic (if-else if-else structure) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code prompts for four coordinates ('Enter x1 and y1:', 'Enter x2 and y2:')
Uses Math.sqrt for distance calculation
No use of conditional statements (if/else) to check grading ranges
Final output is 'The distance of the two points is...'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted the code for a different programming assignment (likely a distance formula exercise) instead of the Grade Calculator program.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt and ensure you are submitting the correct file containing the implementation for the 'Grade Calculator' assignment.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code base is dedicated to solving a distinct, identifiable problem (distance between points) that bears no resemblance to the requested problem (grade calculation).

evidence.note: The core logic reads four double values (coordinates) and calculates geometric distance, completely ignoring the grade input, range checking, and letter output required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to be solving a distance calculation problem between two coordinate points
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Code computes Euclidean distance instead of performing grade range checks
Output is a decimal distance value, not a letter grade
Input prompts request coordinates, not a grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely a file submission error or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment. The student may have submitted a template or previous assignment by accident, or misread which problem to solve.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start from scratch or carefully re-read the assignment requirements. The problem requires: (1) Read one numeric grade, (2) Use if/else-if/else statements to check grade ranges, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem. The code reads four values and computes distance; the assignment requires reading one grade and mapping to a letter.

evidence.note: Class name and variable declarations are for distance calculation, not grade calculation
Reads four coordinate values instead of one grade value
Computes and outputs Euclidean distance; should instead check grade ranges and output letter grade

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade-to-letter mapping
misconceptions.description: The student wrote an entire program to compute the Euclidean distance between two points instead of a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to write a program that reads coordinates for two points and computes the distance between them using the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read one numeric grade from 0 to 100 (typically as an int or double), then use conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to check which range the grade falls into (90-100, 80-89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade A, B, C, D, or F.
symptoms: The program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
All variables represent point coordinates and intermediate distance calculations, with no variable for grade or letter grade.
The program uses Math.sqrt and the distance formula instead of any conditional logic for grade ranges.
The output is a numeric distance with the message 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: X'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem statement or reuse of code from a different exercise (distance between points) without adapting it to the grade-calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the algorithm directly from it: (1) read a single numeric grade from the user, (2) use an if/else-if/else chain to test which grade range the number falls into, and (3) print the correct letter grade. Ignore unrelated previous exercises when starting a new problem.
related_concepts: Designing conditional logic for numeric ranges
Separating different programming tasks and files
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every key element of the code (class name, variable names, prompts, calculations, and output) matches a distance-between-points problem and none of the required grade-calculation behavior (single grade input, conditionals, letter output) is present.

evidence.snippet:
public class DistanceBetweenPoints {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
evidence.note: The class and overall program are clearly framed as a distance-between-points calculator, not a grade calculator.
All main data variables are coordinates of two points; there is no variable representing a numeric grade or a letter grade.
The program reads four doubles corresponding to two points instead of a single numeric grade value.
Core computation is the Euclidean distance formula, unrelated to grade thresholds or conditional logic.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output reports a numeric distance instead of a letter grade such as 'Letter grade: B'.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points (a likely solution to a different, previous problem) instead of the required Grade Calculator program. None of the required algorithmic tasks (reading a single grade, using conditional logic to determine a letter grade) were implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the provided code fulfills the requirements of the Grade Calculator problem, or they mistakenly uploaded the wrong file/solution for this specific question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements (if/else if/else) to map that number to an A, B, C, D, or F letter grade based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of a letter grade.
Program prompts for four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one.
File name and class name ('DistanceBetweenPoints') reflect the wrong problem.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced file, submission error, or failure to understand the core objective of the assignment (Q3 requires a grade calculator, not a distance calculator).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement (Q3) and submit the correct code that implements the logic for converting a numeric grade (0-100) into its corresponding letter grade (A-F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code provided is explicitly a solution to calculating the distance between two points, which is entirely irrelevant to the Grade Calculator problem statement.

evidence.note: The class name explicitly states the wrong program objective.
The code inputs two separate points (four values) instead of a single grade.
The program computes and outputs the distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem submission - submitted distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student submitted working code for a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of implementing a grade calculator. This indicates either a file organization error or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this problem is asking for distance calculation between coordinate pairs, or submitted code from the wrong assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment explicitly asks for a grade calculator that reads ONE numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code has class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of 'GradeCalculator'
Reads four double values (two coordinate pairs) instead of one grade
Declares variables x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of grade-related variables
Uses distance formula (sqrt of sum of squared differences) instead of grade range logic
Outputs 'The distance of the two points is X' instead of 'Letter grade: X'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from a different assignment, likely due to file management/copy-paste error OR did not carefully read the problem statement before implementing.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: 1) Read the problem statement carefully. 2) Create a new program that reads a single grade value. 3) Use if-else statements to check: if (grade >= 90) print 'A'; else if (grade >= 80) print 'B'; etc. 4) Test with the sample input (85 should give 'Letter grade: B').
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence - the code is unambiguously solving a different problem. Multiple indicators confirm this: wrong class name, wrong variable names, wrong input format, wrong computation, wrong output format.

evidence.note: Class name and variable declarations are for distance calculation, not grade conversion
Reads two coordinate pairs instead of a single grade value. Should read only one numeric input.
Implements Euclidean distance formula instead of grade range checking with if-else statements

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Outputs distance value instead of letter grade. Should output 'Letter grade: [A/B/C/D/F]'

misconceptions.name: Incorrect input format - reads multiple values instead of single grade
misconceptions.description: Even setting aside the wrong problem, the code reads four separate double inputs instead of one numeric grade value. The problem specifies reading a single grade (0-100).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they should read multiple input values in sequence using repeated nextDouble() calls.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this assignment, read exactly ONE numeric value representing the grade. The input format should match the sample: 'Enter grade: ' then read one integer or double value.
symptoms: Code calls input.nextDouble() four times instead of once
Prompts are for coordinate pairs, not grades
Sample run shown in problem requires only one input, but code requires four
misconceptions.root_cause: Student confused this problem with a different assignment that required reading multiple coordinate values
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace all input code with a single prompt and read: Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in); System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code definitively reads four values when the problem and sample run show only one input is needed.

evidence.note: Four separate input reads instead of one
